titleStmt.title: Tracking-Error-Based Universal Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Output Tracking of Nonlinear Systems with Completely Unknown Dynamics

analytic.title: Tracking-Error-Based Universal Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Output Tracking of Nonlinear Systems with Completely Unknown Dynamics

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2017.2697399, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems Manuscript received May 19, 2016; revised January 23, 2017; accepted April 16, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, an universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme using output tracking error is proposed for practical tracking control of a class of nonlinear systems with unmeasured states and completely unknown perturbed dynamics including unknown dynamics and/or external disturbances. A tracking error system with measurable output is first derived from the output tracking problem, and unmeasured states are observed by an universal fuzzy state observer (UFSO), whereby adaptive fuzzy approximators and an universal adaptive gain are employed to estimate unknown dynamics and dominant unknown residuals, respectively. In conjunction with the rescaled UFSO and observation errors, the UAFC using output tracking error feedback is explicitly constructed, in a recursive manner, by employing the command filtered backstepping technique, whereby intermediate virtual signals and their first derivatives associated with complex dynamics can be reconstructed by second-order filters. Furthermore, adaptive mechanisms for fuzzy approximators and the universal gain pertaining to the UFSO and UAFC are derived from the Lyapunov synthesis. Theoretical analysis proves that all signals of the closed-loop system are bounded and the output tracking error and observation error can converge to an arbitrarily small region determined by a prescribed accuracy. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed UAFC scheme.

Index Terms-Universal adaptive fuzzy control, universal fuzzy state observer, tracking error feedback control, practical output tracking control, target tracking, completely unknown dynamics, command filtered backstepping.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: W ITHIN THE control community, the output tracking control problem of nonlinear systems characterized by diverse structural and/or parametric nonlinearities is of significant importance and a challenging issue in both theory and practical applications [1]. The main objective of output tracking is to design, if possible, a feedback control law such that the controlled system can track the desired signal with asymptotic/exponential [2] or finite-time [3], [4] convergence.

To be specific, if the desired output (and/or undesired disturbance) is governed by an exosystem, the output tracking (and/or disturbance rejection) problem can be treated as the output regulation problem and has been comprehensively addressed by the output regulation theory [5], which stems from the well-known internal model principle (IMP) [6] involved in linear systems. In the presence of parametric uncertainties within the composite system including the controlled plant and the exosystem, the robust output regulation theory [7]- [9] can provide a mathematically perfect solution if and only if a set of nonlinear partial differential equations, i.e., the regulator equations, are solvable. In the case of unmeasurable system states, output-feedback-based control can also be achieved under detectable conditions. Actually, the exosystem can only specify a family of reference signals with linear dynamics to be tracked since it is extremely challenging, and even impossible, to solve the regulator equations with a nonlinear exosystem. Nevertheless, unknown and/or unmodeled dynamics pertaining to the controlled system and/or desired signal cannot be handled in the framework of output regulation theory since the regulator equations are obviously unsolvable for unknown nonlinearities and disturbances. Interestingly, external undesirable signals can be exactly rejected by finite-time disturbance observers developed in [10] under a mild condition similar to the IMP.

On the other hand, the backstepping technique [11] with a recursive design procedure provides a powerful tool for tracking control of nonlinear lower-triangular systems with both matched and mismatched uncertainties. Due to the recursively repeated differentiation on intermediate virtual signals, the desired output to be tracked and system nonlinearities are required to be sufficiently smooth with bounded derivatives, and thereby resulting in the so-called "explosion of terms" [12]. Accordingly, a series of first-order filters are employed in the dynamic surface control (DSC) [13] method whereby the derivative of a virtual signal defined intermediately can be individually reconstructed, and the couplings among recursive differentiations can be successively removed, and thereby avoiding the "explosion of terms" problem. Furthermore, second-order command filters together with compensated tracking errors are included in the command filtered backstepping (CFBS) [14] approach which can provide an arbitrarily close solution to that of the standard backstepping technique as long as the bandwidths of the command filters are large enough. It should be noted that the foregoing approaches including the backstepping, DSC and CFBS require the sys-tem dynamics to be feedback linearizable and continuously differentiable. Nevertheless, due to the finite escape time issue [15], certain growth (e.g., Lipschitz) conditions [16] on system nonlinearities are additionally required to design an observerbased output feedback controller if the system states are unmeasurable. In this context, the presence of unknown dynamics and/or disturbances would make the previous approaches not suitable for both state and output feedback controller design.

In combination with fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) [17], neural networks (NNs) [18] and fuzzy neural networks (FNNs) [19], numerous achievements on the adaptive-approximation-based control schemes [20] have been established to handle complex dynamics and/or external disturbances which are inherently nonlinear and essentially unknown, and cannot be tackled by traditional approaches. To this end, the foregoing intelligent tools including the FLS, NN and FNN are employed as linear-in-parameter (LIP) or nonlinear-in-parameter (NLIP) approximators which can online estimate unknown dynamics by virtue of their adaptive mechanism on free parameters. In the early stage, fuzzy sets and/or hidden nodes are predefined for the LIP approximator with a fixed structure which allows only output weights to be adapted [21]- [32]. Obviously, the LIP approximation requires a priori knowledge on input variables of interest and poor estimation may occur due to the limited approximation ability of fixed structure. Recently, selforganizing FNNs (SOFNNs) [33]- [36] have been developed to realize the NLIP approximators whereby both structural and parametric information [37] can be adaptively updated, and thereby enhancing identification accuracy. Especially for complex systems with fully unknown dynamics and/or strong disturbances, e.g, robot manipulators [38], unmanned surface vehicles [39]- [41], and circuit systems [42], [43], the SOFNN based adaptive robust control schemes can achieve superior performance in terms of both tracking control and dynamics identification. In the case of unmeasurable system states, an approximation-based state observer, e.g., neural state observer [44] and fuzzy state observer [45], is desirable for output feedback control of nonlinear systems with unknown dynamics and/or disturbances. It should be noted that the Lipschitz condition on system nonlinearities is still required for the fuzzy/neural observer design [46], [47]. Nevertheless, the system output is required to be directly measurable in addition that, at least, the upper bound of the desired output and its first derivative are available. In this context, if only the discrepancy between the actual and desired outputs can be measured, the previous fuzzy/neural state-observer-based output feedback tracking control approach would become infeasible.

In practice, the tracking error might be the only available signal directly measured from the composite tracking system. In this context, unknown dynamics and/or disturbances pertaining to the tracking system including the controlled plant and desired signal would prevent the tracking error from converging to zero. In contrast with asymptotic tracking, practical output tracking via adding a power integrator [48] has been widely pursued by using the tracking error as a feedback signal. By constructing a reduced-order homogeneous observer and using an universal scaling constant [49], practical global output feedback tracking control of a class of nonlinear systems has been achieved in [50], whereby system nonlinearities need to satisfy high-order growth of unmeasurable states. Motivated by the idea of universal control approaches in [51], [52], the growth rates and upper bounds of constraints on system nonlinearities have been further relaxed to be completely unknown in [53], [54] since the gains within the state observer can be increasingly updated according to tracking and observation errors. Even though the universal gain can adapt unknown growth rates and upper bounds, it still requires that perturbed nonlinearities satisfy specific homogeneity conditions of unmeasurable states since the perturbation terms can only be scaled down by the universal gain. By virtue of adding an universal power integrator [55], flexible degrees of homogeneous have been incorporated to mask rich diversities in integrator powers rather than simply positive odd integers. Even so, output tracking control (even in practical manner) via tracking error of nonlinear systems with completely unknown dynamics remains largely open.

In this paper, we focus on an extremely challenging problem for practical output tracking control of uncertain nonlinear systems within intractable settings whereby system nonlinearities and the desired output to be tracked are completely unknown, and only the tracking error is measurable. Note that only the discrepancy between controlled system output and the desired one is available for controller design. The stabilization of the tracking error dynamics with a measurable output would benefit from the preliminary output tracking problem. Since both perturbed dynamics and desired output are completely unavailable, the traditional Luenberger or highgain observers become inapplicable to the foregoing tracking error system. In this context, fuzzy approximators and an adaptive gain, which are incorporated into a state observer, are employed to handle unknown dynamics and unknown residuals, respectively, and thereby contributing to an universal fuzzy state observer (UFSO) for unmeasured states of the tracking error system. Combining with the proposed UFSO, an universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme using output tracking error feedback is explicitly constructed by incorporating command filters into the backstepping technique, whereby differentiations of intermediate virtual signals can be reconstructed by a series of second-order filters. Furthermore, tracking errors between the rescaled UFSO and filtered outputs of virtual control signals, and the rescaled observation error are used to facilitate the UAFC scheme together with adaptive laws for UFSO parameters. Using the Lyapunov approach, theoretical analysis shows that all signals of the closed-loop system are bounded, and both tracking and observation errors can be made arbitrarily small by a prescribed accuracy.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II gives mathematical background and formulates the output tracking control problem associated with a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. The universal fuzzy state observer (UFSO) and the universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme via feedback of output tracking error are addressed in Sections III and IV, respectively. The closed-loop system stability analysis is presented in Section V. Simulation studies are conducted in Section VI. Conclusions are drawn in Section VII.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND MATHEMATICAL BACKGROUND
A. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider the following class of uncertain nonlinear systems:
div.formula: ẋ1 = x 2 + η 1 (x x x, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 1 , d d d 1 (t)) . . . ẋn-1 = x n + η n-1 (x x x, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ n-1 , d d d n-1 (t)) ẋn = u + η n (x x x, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ n , d d d n (t)) y = x 1 -y d (t)(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x x x = [x 1 , • • • , x n ] T ∈ R n , u ∈ R
η i : R n × R × R mi → R, i = 1, 2, • • •
div.p: , n represent unknown continuous nonlinearities pertaining to system dynamics, uncertainties and disturbances.

Inspired by the output regulation theory [5], [7], we consider the case where the output signal y := x 1 -y d is measurable only and is allowed in the output tracking controller design. In this context, system output x 1 and the desired signal y d do not need to be measured directly, and thereby obviously saving the cost of measurement equipments and sensors. Certainly, the output (tracking error) feedback controller design and synthesis under the aforementioned setting would become much more challenging since system output x 1 and desired signal y d are unavailable and cannot explicitly appear in the feedback control law.
To facilitate the controller design and synthesis, we only require a mild constraint on the unmeasured target y d as follows:
Assumption 1. The desired signal y d (t) is continuously differentiable. Moreover, there is an unknown positive constant
div.formula: M ≥ 0 such that sup t≥0 {|y d (t)|, | ẏd (t)|} ≤ M .
div.p: Under Assumption 1, our control objective is to design an universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme via feedback of the output tracking error (i.e., y) for practical output tracking of a large class of uncertain nonlinear systems (1) with uncertainties, unknown external disturbances as well as unmeasurable states x x x, given some desired output y d (t), whereby the bound, i.e., M , is not necessarily known. [22]- [30], [45]- [47] since the desired output y d (t) and lumped unknown dynamics η i (•) are actually allowed to be completely unknown, simultaneously, and only the discrepancy between the actual and desired outputs is available for feedback controller design. Remark 2. It should be emphasized that any constraints in the previous literature [50], [53] and [54]

div.head: Remark 1. In this context, the foregoing tracking error feedback-based control problem of system (1) becomes extremely challenging and remains largely open in the literature
div.formula: on unknown nonlinearities η i (•), i = 1, 2, • • • , n have been completely
div.p: alleviated in this paper. As a consequence, we do not need any a priori knowledge on system dynamics.

div.head: B. Mathematical Background
div.p: In order to realize the aforementioned UAFC scheme, fuzzy logic systems (FLS) are employed to be uncertainty estimators embedded in state observers, and thereby leading to fuzzy state observers (FSO) which will be addressed in details in Section III. In what follows, preliminaries on the universal approximation ability of an FLS are presented in brief.
A FLS f F (•) is composed of a group of fuzzy rules in the following form:
div.formula: Rule l : IF x 1 is A l 1 , and • • • and x n is A l n , THEN f F (x 1 , • • • , x n ) is B l , l = 1, 2, • • • , N (2) where x x x = [x 1 , • • • , x n ] T ∈ R n are input variables, A l i , i = 1, 2, • • • , n
div.p: and B l are input and output fuzzy sets of the lth fuzzy rule, and N is the number of total fuzzy rules.
Using singleton fuzzifier, center average defuzzification and product inference [17] yields the following overall description:
div.formula: f F (x x x) = θ θ θ T φ φ φ(x x x)(3)
div.p: where
div.formula: θ θ θ = [θ 1 , • • • , θ N ] T , θ l = max fF∈R µ B l (f F ), µ B l (•)
div.p: is the membership function of fuzzy set B l , and fuzzy basis functions
div.formula: φ φ φ(x x x) = [φ 1 (x x x), • • • , φ N (x x x)]
div.p: T are defined as follows:
div.formula: φ l (x x x) = n i=1 µ A l i (x i ) N l=1 µ A l i (x i )(4)
div.p: where µ A l i (x i ) is the membership function of fuzzy set A l i . In this context, a key result on approximation ability of the FLS in (3) which will be frequently used in the observer and controller design throughout this work is reproduced here for the convenience of readers.

div.head: Lemma 1 ([17]
div.p: ). For a continuous function f (x x x) defined on a compact set Ω ∈ R n , given any positive constant ǫ > 0, there exists a FLS such that
div.formula: sup x x x∈Ω |f (x x x) -f F (x x x; θ θ θ)| ≤ ǫ (5
div.p: where f F (•) is defined by (3).

div.head: III. UNIVERSAL FUZZY STATE OBSERVER DESIGN
div.p: Recall that only the measurable output tracking error y := x 1 -y d is available for feedback controller design and synthesis, and all system states x 1 , • • • , x n are required to be reconstructed for feedback control. Nevertheless, the unknown nonlinearities η i (•) in system (1) destroy the wellknown lower-triangular form which admits the backstepping design.
In this context, we employ a coordinate transformation z z z = π π π(x x x) where z z z = [z 1 , • • • , z n ] T is as follows:
and convert the original tracking control problem of system (1) to a stabilization problem of the following system:
div.formula: ż1 = z 2 + f 1 (z z z, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 1 , d d d 1 (t), y d , ẏd ) ż2 = z 3 + f 2 (z z z, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 2 , d d d 2 (t), y d ) . . . żn-1 = z n + f n-1 (z z z, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ n-1 , d d d n-1 (t), y d ) żn = u + f n (z z z, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ n , d d d n (t), y d ) y = z 1(7)
div.p: where
div.formula: f 1 (•) = η 1 (z 1 + y d , • • • , z n , u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 1 , d d d 1 (t)) -ẏd (8) f i (•) = η i (z 1 + y d , • • • , z n , u, ϑ ϑ ϑ i , d d d i (t)) , i = 2, • • • , n (9)
div.p: By Lemma 1, the continuous function f i (•) in ( 8) and ( 9) can be approximated by a FLS as follows:
div.formula: f i (Z Z Z i ) = θ θ θ * T i φ φ φ * i (Z Z Z i ) + ǫ i , i = 1, 2, • • • , n(10)
div.p: where
div.formula: Z Z Z i = [z z z T , u, d d d T i ] T ∈ Z i ⊂ R n+mi+1 are input variables, |ǫ i | ≤ ǭi is the optimal approximation error, φ φ φ * ż2 = z3 + θ θ θ T 2 φ φ φ 2 (ẑ z z 2 ) -L 2 k 2 z1 + θ θ θ * T 2 φ φ φ 2 + ǫ 2 . . . żn-1 = zn + θ θ θ T n-1 φ φ φ n-1 -L n-1 k n-1 z1 + θ θ θ * T n-1 φ φ φ n-1 + ǫ n-1 żn = θ θ θ T n φ φ φ n -L n k n z1 + θ θ θ * T n φ φ φ n + ǫ n (14
div.p: where
div.formula: zi = z i -ẑi , θ θ θ i = θ θ θ * i -θ θ θ i , and φ φ φ i = φ φ φ * i -φ φ φ i , i = 1, 2, • • • , n.
div.p: Applying the following rescaling transformation:
div.formula: e i = ẑi L i , ε i = zi L i(15)
div.p: to ( 12) and ( 14), respectively, yields
div.formula: ė e e = LA A Ae e e + Lk k kε 1 + L L L f f f F + ū u u - L L D D De e e(16)

div.p: Since B B B in ( 21) is a Hurwitz matrix, there exists a symmetric positive definite matrix P P P = P P P T > 0 such that [56] B B B T P P P + P P PB B B ≤ -2I I I and D D DP P P + P P PD D D ≥ 0 (22) where
div.formula: P P P := [p p p 1 , • • • , p p p n ] T with p p p i = [p i1 , • • • , p in ] T .
div.p: Remark 3. In addition to the embedded fuzzy estimator, the UFSO ( 12) is characterized with an "universal" gain L which is dynamically adapted by (13), and thereby contributing to rescaled dynamics of the UFSO in (16) and its observation errors in (17), respectively. More importantly, the universal gain L plays a key role in developing the so-called universal adaptive controller since unknown junk dynamics are required to be significantly suppressed by a high but bounded gain.

div.head: IV. PROPOSED UNIVERSAL ADAPTIVE FUZZY CONTROL SCHEME
div.p: Combining with the proposed UFSO in ( 16), an universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme using output tracking error feedback will be explicitly constructed in a recursive manner. By incorporating command filters [14] into the backstepping technique [11], the differentiation of an intermediate virtual signal and itself can be simultaneously reconstructed by a second-order filter. Since command filter errors can be made arbitrarily small [14], tracking errors between the rescaled UFSO in (16) and filtered outputs of virtual control signals, and the rescaled observation error ε 1 in ( 17) are used to facilitate the design of UAFC together with adaptive laws for parameters θ θ θ i in the sequel.
Step 1: Let ζ 1 = e 1 and consider the first-order dynamics of the rescaled UFSO system (16) as follows:
div.formula: ζ1 = Le 2 + Lk 1 ε 1 + 1 L θ θ θ T 1 φ φ φ 1 - L L ζ 1(23)
div.p: Taking e 2 as the virtual control input whose ideal signal is given by
div.formula: e * 2 = - 1 L Lζ 1 + 1 L θ θ θ T 1 φ φ φ 1 + Lk 1 ε 1 (24) yields ζ1 = -L + L L ζ 1 + L (e 2 -e * 2 )(25)
div.p: Inspired by the command filtered backstepping (CFBS) [14] technique, a command filter is employed to avoid differentiating the virtual signal e * 2 as follows:

The filter error ẽ2 := ē2 -e * 2 represents the unachieved portion of the ideal signal e * 2 , and can be employed to generate a filtered version of ẽ2 as follows:

div.p: where γ 1 > 0 and σ 1 > 0 are user-defined parameters.
Step i (i = 2, • • • , n -1): Consider the tracking error as follows:
div.formula: ζ i = e i -ēi (31
div.p: where ēi is the filtered output of a command filter by passing through the previous virtual control signal e * i , i.e., ëi + 2ς i ω i ėi + ω 2 i ēi = ω 2 i e * i , with ēi (0) = e * i (0) and ėi (0) = 0 (32) where ω i > 0 and 0 < ς i ≤ 1 are design parameters, and the signals ēi and ėi are the command filtered output of e * i and ė * i , respectively. Together with (16), taking e i+1 as the current virtual control input whose ideal signal is governed by
div.formula: e * i+1 = - 1 L Lζ i + 1 L i θ θ θ T i φ φ φ i + Lk i ε 1 + Lζ i-1 -ėi(33)
yields ζi = -L + L L i ζ i -Lζ i-1 + L e i+1 -e * i+1(34)
div.p: Similarly, a command filter is employed to avoid differentiating the virtual signal e * i+1 as follows:
div.formula: ëi+1 + 2ς i+1 ω i+1 ėi+1 + ω 2 i+1 ēi+1 = ω 2 i+1 e * i+1 , with ēi+1 (0) = e * i+1(
div.p: 0) and ėi+1 (0) = 0 (35) where ω i+1 > 0 and 0 < ς i+1 ≤ 1 are design parameters, and the signals ēi+1 and ėi+1 are the command filtered output of e * i+1 and ė * i+1 , respectively. In order to compensate for the filter error ẽi+1 := ēi+1e * i+1 , a filtered signal is generated by
div.formula: ṡi = -L + L L i s i -Ls i-1 + L (s i+1 + ẽi+1 ) , s i (0) = 0(36)
div.p: where s i+1 will be determined in the next step. Accordingly, we have the following compensated tracking error dynamics:
div.formula: ξi = -L + L L i ξ i -Lξ i-1 + Lξ i+1(37)
div.p: with
div.formula: ξ j = s j -ζ j , ζ j = e j -ēj j = i -1, i, i + 1(38)
div.p: The adaptive parameter θ θ θ i is dynamically adapted by
div.formula: θ θ θ i = γ i 1 L i p 1i ε 1 + ζ i φ φ φ i (ẑ z z i ) -σ i θ θ θ i (39
div.p: where γ i > 0 and σ i > 0 are user-defined parameters.
Step n: In the last step, consider the following tracking error:
div.formula: ζ n = e n -ēn(40)
div.p: where ēn is the filtered output of a command filter by passing through the previous virtual control signal e * n , and is determined by (35)
div.formula: with i = n -1.
div.p: Selecting the actual control input u in (16) as follows:
div.formula: u = -L n Lζ n + 1 L n θ θ θ T n φ φ φ n + Lk n ε 1 + Lζ n-1 -ėn(41)
div.p: yields
div.formula: ζn = -L + L L n ζ n -Lζ i-1(42)
div.p: Using the final compensation s n = 0 results in the compensated tracking error ξ n = ζ n .
Moreover, the adaptive law for the estimate θ θ θ n is given by
div.formula: θ θ θ n = γ n 1 L n p 1n ε 1 + ζ n φ φ φ n (ẑ z z n ) -σ n θ θ θ n (43
div.p: where γ n > 0 and σ n > 0 are user-defined parameters.
Remark 4. Combining with ( 25), ( 34) and ( 42) contributes to the entire tracking error dynamics as follows:
div.formula: ζ ζ ζ = G G Gζ ζ ζ + H H Hẽ e e (44
with ζ ζ ζ = [ζ 1 , • • • , ζ n ] T , ẽ e e = [ẽ 1 , • • • , ẽn ] T ,

div.p: In this context, there exists a positive constant δ > 0 such that
Moreover, removing the perturbation of the filter error ẽ e e from the tracking error dynamics (44) results in the following compensated tracking error:
div.formula: ξ ξ ξ = G G Gξ ξ ξ (46
where ξ ξ ξ = [ξ 1 , • • • , ξ n ] T .
div.p: Selecting the Lyapunov function V ξ = 1 2 ξ ξ ξ T ξ ξ ξ and using (46) yields Vξ ≤ -L ξ ξ ξ 2 ≤ -ξ ξ ξ 2 , and immediately implies that the compensated tracking error ξ ξ ξ can exponentially converge to the origin. Remark 6. Note from (13) that L ≥ 0 and hence L(t) ≥ L(0) = 1. In this context, the vector field of the closed-loop system ( 13), ( 16), ( 17), (39), (44) and ( 46) is continuously differentiable with respect to its variables, and satisfies the local Lipschitz condition within a neighborhood of the initial condition (e e e(0), ε ε ε(0), ζ ζ ζ(0), ξ ξ ξ(0), θ θ θ i (0), L(0)). As a consequence, the solution (e e e(t), ε ε ε(t), ζ ζ ζ(t), ξ ξ ξ(t), θ θ θ i (t), L(t)) of the closed-loop system ( 13), ( 16), ( 17), ( 39), ( 44) and ( 46) exists and is unique.

div.head: V. STABILITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section, we rigorously analyze the stability of the closed-loop system including plant (1), UFSO (12) and control law governed by ( 24), ( 33) and ( 41) with adaptive parameters given by ( 30), ( 39) and ( 43), and summarize the key result here.

Theorem 1. Under Assumptions 1 and 2, practical output tracking control of uncertain nonlinear system (1) with unmeasured states can be solved by employing the proposed UAFC scheme including the feedback control law in ( 24)-( 33)-( 41), UFSO given by (12), adaptive estimates θ θ θ i governed by ( 30)-( 39)- (43), and the universal adaptive gain L(t) governed by (13). Moreover, all signals of the closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded, the rescaled UFSO output e 1 and its observation error ε 1 can be made arbitrarily small by a prescribed accuracy λ > 0, and there exists a finite time T λ > 0 such that the output tracking error y
div.formula: := x 1 -y d satisfies |y(t)| ≤ λ, ∀ t ≥ T λ .
div.p: Proof. Consider the following Lyapunov function:
div.formula: V = 1 2 ε ε ε T P P Pε ε ε + ζ ζ ζ T ζ ζ ζ + n i=1 γ -1 i θ θ θ T i θ θ θ i(47)
div.p: where
div.formula: ε ε ε = [ε 1 , • • • , ε n ] T , ζ ζ ζ = [ζ 1 , • • • , ζ n ] T , θ θ θ i = θ θ θ * i -θ
div.p: θ θ i , the symmetric positive definite matrix P P P is derived from (22), and γ i > 0, i = 1, 2, • • • , n are adaptive gains.
Together with (22), the time derivative of V along the dynamics ( 17) and ( 44) can be obtained as follows:
Lε ε ε T B B B T P P P + P P PB B B ε ε ε -L 2L ε ε ε T (D D DP P P + P P PD D D) ε ε ε

Proposition 1. The adaptive gain L(t) determined by ( 13) is bounded, i.e., L(t) ≤ L < +∞, ∀ t ≥ T λ for a finite time T λ > 0. By Propositions 1 and 2, we immediately have 1 ≤ L ≤ L < +∞, and y and ẑ1 are bounded. Combining with (13), we can conclude that L is bounded, and L(t) is continuously differentiable. Together with ( 7) and ( 12), we further conclude that ẏ and ż1 are bounded, and the derivative of the function h(y, ẑ1 , L) =

exists and is bounded. In this context, using the Barbalat's lemma [1] gives lim t→+∞ L(t) = 0. It follows that for any initial condition (x x x(0), ẑ z z(0)), given a tracking tolerance λ > 0, there exists a finite time 13), the following inequality holds:

This concludes the proof.

div.head: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In order to demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed UAFC scheme, we consider two numerical examples and a real-world application for performance evaluation and comprehensive comparisons.

div.head: A. Performance Evaluation on a Non-Triangular Nonlinear System with Completely Unknown Dyanmics
div.p: We consider the output tracking problem of the following non-triangular nonlinear system with completely unknown perturbations:
div.formula: ẋ1 = x 2 + η 1 (x x x, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 1 , d d d 1 (t)) ẋ2 = u + η 2 (x x x, u, ϑ ϑ ϑ 2 , d d d 2 (t)) y = x 1 -y d (t)(60)
div.p: where x x x = [x 1 , x 2 ] T ∈ R 2 , u ∈ R and y ∈ R are system states, control input and the measurable output, respectively, y d (t) is the desired trajectory to be tracked, d d d i : R + → R mi , i = 1, 2 are unknown external disturbances, and η i : R n × R × R mi → R, i = 1, 2 are unknown continuous nonlinearities pertaining to system dynamics, uncertainties and disturbances.
To facilitate the performance evaluation, unknown nonlinearities η 1 and η 2 are assumed as
div.formula: η 1 (x x x, u, ϑ 1 , d 1 (t)) = x 1/3 2 cos 2 x 1 + d 1 (t) sin(ϑ 1 u) and η 2 (x x x, u, ϑ 2 , d 2 (t)) = d 2 (t)x 1 + sin(ϑ 2 x 2 u
div.p: ) with unknown parameters ϑ 1 and ϑ 2 , and time-varying external disturbances which are simply assumed by ϑ 1 = π/4, ϑ 2 = π/8, d 1 (t) = cos 2 (πt/6), and d 2 (t) = cos(πt/2).

It is not difficult to see that the nonlinearities η 1 and η 2 cannot be handled by the previous approaches including adaptive fuzzy/neural [46], [47] or adaptive universal [50], [53], [54] methods, since the Lipschitz and growth conditions have been violated. In addition, the desired trajectory y d (t) is generated by y d (t) = sin t which obviously satisfies Assumption 1, i.e., sup t≥0 {|y d (t)|, | ẏd (t)|} ≤ M for a positive constant M > 0 which is not necessarily known.
Applying the coordinate transformation (6) to system (60) yields
div.formula: ż1 = z 2 + f 1 (z z z, u, ϑ 1 , d 1 (t), y d , ẏd ) ż2 = u + f 2 (z z z, u, ϑ 2 , d 2 (t), y d ) y = z 1(61)
div.p: where z z z = [z 1 , z 2 ] T , and nonlinearities f 1 (•) = x 1/3 2 cos 2 x 1 + cos 2 (πt/6) sin(πu/4) -cos t and f 2 (•) = x 1 cos(πt/2) + sin(πx 2 u/8) are actually unknown.
Design the following fuzzy state observer:
div.formula: ż1 = ẑ2 + θ θ θ T 1 φ φ φ 1 (ẑ 1 ) + Lk 1 (y -ẑ1 ) ż2 = u + θ θ θ T 2 φ φ φ 2 (ẑ z z) + L 2 k 2 (y -ẑ1 )(62)
div.p: where the universal gain L > 0 is adaptively updated by
with
div.formula: L(0) = 1. The fuzzy basis functions φ φ φ 1 (ẑ 1 ) = [φ 11 (ẑ 1 ), • • • , φ 1N1 (ẑ 1 )] T and φ φ φ 2 (ẑ z z) = [φ 21 (ẑ z z), • • • , φ 2N2 (ẑ z z)] T with N 1 = n 1 and N 2 = n 1 n 2
div.p: are composed by fuzzy membership functions as follows:
where
div.formula: µ jij (ẑ j ) = exp - (ẑ j -c jij ) 2 ̺ 2 j , j = 1, 2(66)
div.p: with
div.formula: c jij = r j,low + i j ̺ j , i j = 1, 2, • • • , n j .
div.p: Applying the rescaling transformation (15) to (62) yields
div.formula: ė1 = Le 2 + 1 L θ θ θ T 1 φ φ φ 1 (ẑ 1 ) + Lk 1 ε 1 - L L e 1 ė2 = 1 L 2 u + 1 L 2 θ θ θ T 2 φ φ φ 2 (ẑ z z) + Lk 2 ε 1 - L L e 2(67)
div.p: where ε 1 = y-ẑ1 L . Next, according to the recursive design procedure in Section IV, we can design the control law u in system (67) by θ θ

Simulation results on desired and actual outputs, i.e., y d and x 1 , are shown in Fig. 1, whereby the output tracking error y together with its UFSO observation ẑ1 shown in Fig. 2 demonstrates that the proposed UAFC scheme using the control action shown in Fig. 3 can achieve practical output tracking with a predefined tolerance λ > 0, and the observed output ẑ2 shown in Fig. 4 is able to estimate well the unmeasurable state z 2 . Rescaled fuzzy observations e 1 , e 2 and rescaled observation errors ε 1 , ε 2 are shown in Figs. 5 and6, respectively, from which we can see that fuzzy observations and their errors are uniformly ultimately bounded within a small region of the origin. By virtue of the command filter (70), direct differentiation of the intermediate virtual signal e * 2 is reconstructed by the filtered output ē2 shown in Fig. 7, which eventually converges to a very small neighborhood of zero. Accordingly, as shown in Fig. 8, rescaled tracking errors ζ 1 and ζ 2 can be made arbitrarily small since the filter error is actually tiny. In essence, the adaptive universal gain L(t) shown in Fig. 9 plays a crucial role in the proposed UAFC scheme. On the one hand, the dynamically increasing parameter L serves as a bounded high gain in control law (68). On the other hand, the universal gain L can suppress generic residuals and renders the output tracking error with a predefined accuracy. It should be noted that the universal gain L is strictly bounded since the adaptive mechanism for increasing L would be frozen once the output tracking error satisfies the tolerance.

div.head: B. Comparisons on a Triangular Nonlinear System Satisfying Growth Condition
div.p: In order to further demonstrate the superiority of the proposed UAFC scheme with an adaptive universal gain L, we conduct comprehensive comparisons with the UAFC scheme without adaptive universal gain, i.e., a fixed gain L = 1, and the UAFC scheme without fuzzy approximators. Actually, the foregoing 2 schemes to be compared exactly degrade to the output-feedback-based adaptive fuzzy control (AFC) [46] and output-feedback-based adaptive universal control (AUC) [53] approaches, respectively. In this context, we consider the following triangular nonlinear system which satisfies the growth condition of the AFC and AUC:
where the desired output y d (t) = sin t and the state x 1 are required to be separately available for the AFC approach.
For a simple and fair comparison, we use the user-defined parameters from the previous example.

Comparison results on output tracking accuracy and observation performance are shown in Figs. 10 and11, respectively, from which we can see that the UAFC scheme with both fuzzy approximation and an adaptive universal gain obviously achieves superior performance in terms of both output tracking and unmeasured state observation. The detailed comparisons are summarized in Table I where the Integrated Absolute Error (IAE) and Integrated Time Absolute Error (ITAE) defined as IAE = t 0 |e(τ )|dτ and ITAE = t 0 t|e(τ )|dτ respectively are used to evaluate the transient and steady-state performance. On the contrary, the UAFC scheme without the universal gain, i.e., the AFC, and the UAFC scheme without fuzzy approximations, i.e., the AUC can only track the system output in a much larger neighborhood of the desired signal, since the AFC without the universal gain can only reconstruct the estimates ẑ1 and ẑ2 with a large observation error and the AUC without fuzzy approximations can hardly observe the unmeasured state z 2 by merely using an universal high gain. In this context, fuzzy approximations which can adaptively estimate unknown dynamics and the universal gain which can dynamically dominate observation errors and/or residuals contribute to precise control of UFSO, and thereby realizing output-tracking-error-feedback-based UAFC scheme which is synthesized in a recursive manner and can achieve practical output tracking with a prescribed accuracy.

div.head: C. Comparisons on an Application to Mass-Spring Mechanical System
div.p: In order to further demonstrate the superiority of the UAFC scheme with application to a physical system, we consider the mass-spring mechanical system with unknown dynamics and disturbances as follows: where x 1 is the displacement from a reference position, u is the control force, y d (t) is the time-varying target, y is the measured output, k = 1 m with the mass m > 0, and F sp (•) is unknown restoring force with disturbances. For the sake of simulation, we assume y d (t) = sin t and
div.formula: ẋ1 = x 2 ẋ2 = ku + F sp (x 1 , d(t)) y = x 1 -y d (t)(74)
F sp (x 1 , d(t)) = d(t)x 1 q i=0 a i x i 1 (75)
div.p: with d(t) = 2 cos(0.1t), q = 4 and a i = 3.

Comparison results with the AFC [46] and the AUC [53] approaches are shown in Fig. 12, from which we can see that the proposed UAFC scheme achieves the most accurate tracking and observation while the AUC method only using an increasingly adapted gain L can hardly track the desired target nor cannot estimate the measured output. Furthermore, comparison results summarized in Table II clearly evaluates the superiority of the UAFC scheme in terms of both tracking and observation performance.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, an universal adaptive fuzzy control (UAFC) scheme via output tracking error feedback has been proposed for practical output tracking of a class of uncertain nonlinear systems with unmeasurable states and completely unknown dynamics including parametric and/or structural uncertainties and external disturbances. An universal gain L dynamically adapted by the errors of both output tracking and observation has been incorporated into the fuzzy state observer design, and thereby contributing to the universal fuzzy state observer (UFSO) which can not only estimate unmeasured states but also suppress completely unknown dynamics. By virtue of the rescaled UFSO dynamics and the command filtered backstepping technique, the UAFC scheme has been explicitly constructed in a recursive manner, whereby differentiations of intermediate virtual signals have been reconstructed by a group of command filters and adaptive parameters pertaining to the UFSO have been derived from the Lyapunov synthesis. As a consequence, theoretical analysis has rigorously proven that all signals of the closed-loop control system are bounded, and the rescaled UFSO output and its observation error can be made arbitrarily small by a prescribed accuracy, and thereby achieving practical output tracking only using output tracking error feedback. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed UAFC scheme in terms of both tracking and observation performance. Clearly, the proposed UAFC scheme provides a powerful tool for target tracking of unmanned vehicles, missiles, mobile robots, etc., whenever only tracking error (discrepancy) can be available.

div.head: APPENDIX A PROOF OF PROPOSITION 1
div.p: Proof. In order to prove the boundedness of the gain L(t), a contradiction argument is employed in the sequel. Suppose that the gain L(t) is unbounded, i.e., lim t→∞ L(t) = +∞. Recall that the adaptive gain L(t) is a nondecreasing function with initial condition L(0) = 1. Hence, there exists a finite time T 1 > 0 and a positive constant α 1 (T 1 ) such that L(t) ≥ max (n + 1) P P P 2 + α 1 λ max (P P P ),
where λ max (P P P ) denotes the maximal eigenvalue of matrix P P P and σ i -α 1 γ -1 i > 0.
